node.text:
Exactly 20 years after 9/11, the architects of the U.S. response can look back with relief that another large-scale attack on American soil never took place.

But that fact has often been used as a blanket justification for many of the most far-reaching, controversial and harmful decisions made in the aftermath of the attacks — the vast expansion of the surveillance state; covert operations to kill or capture suspected terrorists; and the invasion first of Afghanistan, where the attacks were planned, and then Iraq, where they were not.

We spoke to 17 of the most consequential architects of the post-9/11 world to ask them to reflect on the decades of war they helped wage and the domestic defenses they helped erect. Here's what some of them had to say. Link in bio for the full story.

node.title: They created our post-9/11 world. Here’s what they think they got wrong.

Democrats and abortion rights activists are criticizing Texas’ restrictive abortion law — and the Supreme Court’s conservative majority that allowed it to go into effect this week. 

Here’s how some political figures and abortion rights activists responded, in 180 seconds.

node.title: The response to the Texas abortion ban in 180 seconds

node.text: Our Playbook co-authors break down two big storylines of the week & answer your questions about what happens next, both with Roe v. Wade and in Kabul. Featuring two special guests: healthcare reporter Alice Ollstein and national security reporter Alex Ward 👋

node.title: Let’s talk about abortion & Afghanistan with @EugeneDaniels2 & @ryan.lizza

The war is over in Afghanistan. Now what?

node.text:
As the Taliban solidifies its hold over Afghanistan and the Biden administration works to quickly evacuate thousands of American citizens and Afghans, many in Washington are pointing fingers trying to decide who is to blame. 

National security reporter Alex Ward takes a closer look at how the blame game will play out.

https://politi.co/2W4DPQu

node.title: Here’s why Bush, Obama and Trump get blamed for Afghanistan too

node.text:
A defiant President Biden on Monday said he did not regret his decision to withdraw American forces from Afghanistan, while acknowledging that the country's collapse to the Taliban came much sooner than U.S. officials had anticipated.

"I stand squarely behind my decision," he said from the White House. "The truth is this did unfold more quickly than we had anticipated.”

Watch highlights from Biden's speech in 180 seconds. https://politi.co/3xUft8E

node.title: Biden delivers remarks on Afghanistan, in 180 seconds

node.text:
Time is not on Trump's side. The Biden administration saw a major win by passing a bipartisan trillion dollar infrastructure bill that could flood the workforce with thousands of jobs and keep his campaign promise to fix Washington. Since losing the 2020 election, the former president has had a handful of botched attempts to return to the spotlight. 

Ryan Lizza breaks down the dynamics of Trump's return, what's working, what isn't and what to expect next.

node.title: Trump's influence keeps haunting Washington, explained

node.text:
A year after New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo reached new political heights with daily news briefings that enraptured a nation in the throes of a once-in-a-lifetime pandemic, the three-term Democrat announced plans to resign amid growing pressure to leave or face impeachment over allegations that he sexually harassed nearly a dozen women.

“Given the circumstances, the best way I can help now is if I step aside and let the government get back to government,” Cuomo said in a video statement. “Therefore that's what I'll do, because I work for you, and doing the right thing, is doing the right thing for you. Because, as we say, ‘it's not about me, it's about we.’” 

Read more at the link in bio.

https://politi.co/2UaCHK6

node.title: Andrew Cuomo resigns amid sexual harassment scandal

node.text: “Can’t we all agree that it’s better to spread a few jokes and laughs around instead of viruses and Covid?” @mattwuerker  is here with latest Weekend Wrap of political satire and cartoons, from the ongoing fight against the Delta variant to the Cuomo report coming out of New York.

node.title: Is it time to social distance from Gov. Cuomo?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 16, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Dems call in big gun as they face huge Hill tests'.

node.text:
The next few months will push Biden to wield every drop of his influence over Congress.

Democrats are facing internal debates over social programs while trying to beat back GOP resistance on voting rights and steering the U.S. away from economic catastrophe. And in order to avert a government shutdown, Democratic lawmakers are urging Biden to get more directly involved.

Biden appears to be answering the call. The president is getting more involved in Congress’ chaotic fall session as he battles dropping approval ratings, heightened concerns around Covid and criticism over his withdrawal from Afghanistan. On Thursday, he'll speak to Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and Speaker Nancy Pelosi ahead of a critical week for funding the government and lifting the debt ceiling.

Rebounding will depend on whether his spending ambitions are realized and if Democrats can avoid a government shutdown and credit default. But even if he has success on those fronts, he still needs to maintain momentum on Democrats’ elections legislation, which Republicans look certain to torpedo. Link in bio for more. 

📷: Getty 

https://politi.co/3nzVXNm

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 16, 2021. May be an image of monument.

node.text:
Fencing is back up around the Capitol in anticipation of a Sept. 18 rally to defend those arrested during the Jan. 6 attack.

Many of those who participated in January are expected to return to the nation’s capital for Saturday's demonstration. Capitol Police are reportedly preparing for violence and erected protective fencing around the building last night.

Rank-and-file Capitol Police officers have been briefed by leadership about security preparations for the rally. The briefing came after pushback from officers about their lack of advance warning of the risks of the Jan. 6 attack.

The security plan includes a fenced perimeter on the streets immediately surrounding the Capitol building and the Supreme Court, though not around the congressional office buildings nearby. Capitol Police Chief Thomas Manger said that "if everything goes well," the fencing will come down soon after Sept. 18.

Link in bio for more. 

📷: AP, Getty

Photo by POLITICO on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'Lindsey Graham, the one-man PR shop for the Afghan resistance'.

node.text:
Lindsey Graham is taking extraordinary steps to boost Afghanistan’s resistance leaders.

After the Taliban swept into power in Kabul, the South Carolina GOP senator began working behind the scenes to build support in Washington foreign policy circles for Amrullah Saleh, the Afghan opposition leader spearheading the anti-Taliban resistance based in the northeastern province of Panjshir.

Graham has connected resistance leaders to diplomats, lobbyists and influential media figures. He even played the role of TV booker and got Saleh on Fox's Hannity. 

“I want his voice out,” Graham told us. “I’m gonna go all in. [The Taliban are] holding our people hostage... And if we empower them, it will hurt us all over the world.”

There are no indications that the Biden administration is prepared to help the Panjshir resistance, especially given its wobbly status after being overrun by the Taliban. Link in bio for more details. 

📷 Getty

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '"We will be watching their actions very, very closely." -Amb. Linda Thomas-Greenfield on the Taliban UN'.

node.text:
Kabul fell — and Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield was thrust into the spotlight.

Nearly all U.S. Ambassador posts are unfilled. As the Biden administration struggles to get nominees confirmed, Thomas-Greenfield, the U.S. Ambassador to the U.N., has been tasked leading Presidential delegations around the world.

She spoke to @politicoryan in the days following the Taliban’s takeover of Kabul about where she stands with Afghanistan’s ambassador to the U.N. and what’s next for U.S. relations with the Taliban. Link in bio for more on what she had to say.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'NEWSOM SURVIVES'.

node.text:
The results are in: California Gov. Gavin Newsom is here to stay. With 60% of the expected vote in, 67% of voters wanted to keep him in office vs. about 33% of voters who wanted to boot him. (Swipe up via our Story to check the most updated numbers.) 

The prospect of recalling Newsom once seemed like a political fantasy, but it got very real once conservative opponents harnessed frustration with the Democrat’s Covid shutdown orders to qualify the election. Newsom raised some $70 million and enlisted big Democratic names like President Joe Biden, VP Kamala Harris, Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders to boost lukewarm voter enthusiasm in the race and get enough supporters turned out to vote.

The governor now enters the final year of his first term in a strong position. Republicans’ failure to oust Newsom in an off-year special election fueled by conservative grievances suggests they face an uphill fight to defeat him next year. 

Link in bio for more.

📷: AP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 14, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, outdoors and text that says 'ROARS RARBACK BACK VAX FOR THE WIN'.

node.text:
California's recall election is today and getting attention in the nation’s most populous state is no easy feat. Over the last several months, candidates performed outlandish stunts in a desperate bid for attention — including Gov. Gavin Newsom.

Swipe through for just some of the biggest attention getters including: 
➡️ Newsom celebrating California’s economic reopening with a Universal Studios event, surrounded by Minions and a purple-haired Troll.

➡️ Republican John Cox using a live Kodiak bear to illustrate his “unleash the beast” campaign. 

➡️ Youtuber Kevin Paffrath proposing a pipeline to transfer water from the Mississippi to California to solve the state’s drought problems at the one debate he was allowed to partake in. 

Link in bio for more of the most memorable stunts and flubs from the California recall election.

📷: AP, Getty 

https://politi.co/3k4xLk2

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 13, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'The fight over booster shots Inside the escalating tension between Biden's Covid team and the CDC'.

node.text:
Biden's health team is increasingly clashing with the CDC as the administration pushes to begin distributing booster shots widely by Sept. 20.

In the last few months, senior White House and FDA officials have repeatedly accused CDC of withholding critical data needed to develop the booster shot plan — delaying work on the next step of President Biden’s vaccination campaign and making it more difficult to set clear expectations for the public.

One particularly frustrating episode occurred last month, when the agency appeared to publicly reject the administration’s plan to offer boosters to all adults, two officials said. The move blindsided senior officials and further strained already-tenuous relationships. 

But the CDC director has fiercely defended the agency, telling White House officials who have promised to follow the science that the late September target is probably too ambitious. The agency still needs to complete studies that would help provide the rationale for the shots, and they're still waiting for booster data from Moderna and J&J.

“Science takes time,” one exasperated CDC official said. “I don’t know how many times we have to say this.” Link in bio for the full story. 

https://politi.co/3k51vgE

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '"We inherited a deadline. We did not inherit a plan." -Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Afghanistan'.

node.text:
The secretary of State blamed Trump as he defended the Biden administration's messy withdrawal from Afghanistan today. 

“We inherited a deadline. We did not inherit a plan,” Antony Blinken told lawmakers. 

Blinken said the Biden administration was handcuffed by Trump’s agreement with the Taliban, which in part reduced the U.S. troop presence to 2,500 by the time Biden took office. With the Taliban continuing its “relentless” military campaign regardless of that agreement, Blinken said, Biden “immediately faced the choice between ending the war or escalating it.”

Lawmakers from both parties have criticized the Biden administration for not starting the evacuations sooner. The State Department has already acknowledged that thousands of Afghan allies who applied for Special Immigrant Visas were left behind, in addition to several hundred Americans, when the final U.S. troops left Afghanistan on Aug. 31.

Link in bio for the full story. 

📷 AP

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 13, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and standing.

node.text:
Stephanie Grisham is breaking her silence about what she saw in the Trump White House. 

At 1:25 p.m. on Jan. 6, soon after rioters had broken through barricades outside of the Capitol, Melania Trump received a text message from Grisham, who was then her chief of staff.

“Do you want to tweet that peaceful protests are the right of every American, but there is no place for lawlessness and violence?” Grisham asked the first lady.

A minute later, Melania replied with a one-word answer: “No.” At that moment, she was at the White House preparing for a photo shoot of a rug she had selected, according to exclusive excerpts we obtained of Grisham’s forthcoming book, “I’ll Take Your Questions Now: What I Saw in The Trump White House.”

Grisham, a years-long Trump loyalist best known for never holding a press briefing, resigned within hours of that text. Now in her upcoming tell-all, she also details her exchanges with Melania about reaching out to Jill Biden during the transition and her thoughts on whether Melania truly believed the election was illegitimate. 

Melania's office released a statement dismissing Grisham's book as “an attempt to redeem herself after a poor performance” and an attempt to gain relevance and money. 

Link in bio for more details. 

📷 AP

node.text:
Exactly 20 years after 9/11, the architects of the U.S. response can look back with relief that another large-scale attack on American soil never took place.

But that fact has often been used as a blanket justification for many of the most far-reaching, controversial and harmful decisions made in the aftermath of the attacks — the vast expansion of the surveillance state; covert operations to kill or capture suspected terrorists; and the invasion first of Afghanistan, where the attacks were planned, and then Iraq, where they were not.

We spoke to 17 of the most consequential architects of the post-9/11 world to ask them to reflect on the decades of war they helped wage and the domestic defenses they helped erect. Here's what some of them had to say. Link in bio for the full story.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '"I think we overreached at some point." -Paul Wolfowitz'.

node.text:
They created our post-9/11 world. Here's what they think they got wrong (swipe 👈). 

It's been 20 years since the worst terrorist attack in American history killed nearly 3,000 people. The wars since have cost trillions of dollars, the lives of 7,064 American troops and led to a crisis of military veteran suicides, totalling more than 30,000. Thousands of civilians in Iraq and Afghanistan died in conflicts that were either launched in response to 9/11 or grew out of their consequences. 

This summer, as the U.S. began to wind down its military operations in Afghanistan, we approached nearly two dozen of the most consequential architects of the post-9/11 world to ask them to reflect on the decades of war they helped wage and the domestic defenses they helped erect. What do they think they got right? What would they have done differently? 

Some of the most prominent players, like then President George W. Bush, Secretary of State Colin Powell and Condoleezza Rice, who was both national security adviser and secretary of State, declined to be interviewed. But in all, 17 agreed to speak on the record. Together, their testimony offers a unique collection of unfiltered perspectives never before gathered in one place. Swipe 👈 for a preview, or head to the link in bio for the full story.

📷 Gabriella Demczuk for @politicomag

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by POLITICO on September 10, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Biden cracks down on the unvaccinated'.

node.text:
Joe Biden finally figured out he’d been talking to the wrong people.

For months, the president treated the vaccine-resistant with kid gloves, sprinkling words like “unity” into his remarks about and sidestepping others, like “mandate.” 

Now, Covid-19 case numbers are surging. The hard-core opposition is largely unmoved. And those who got vaccinated? They’re driving down his poll numbers.

That's why the president is taking his sharpest course correction to date on a pandemic that has fully reemerged, threatening to derail nascent economic growth and dragging down Biden’s approval rating along with it.

In remarks at the White House Thursday evening, Biden scolded the vaccine resistant, saying that new vaccine mandates the fault of Americans who couldn’t bother to play by the rules. Instead, he said, they played politics with a life-saving vaccine, endangering loved ones and coworkers.

It was a bringing down of the hammer that some Democrats have been urging. For some, Biden still took far too long to get there. Link in bio for more.

📷: Getty
